fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: An Image of the print shop that Gavin's dad worked in.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** How was it working with your dad to try and do the printing? Did you actually get to go to the printer and did he facilitate you through that process? 

**Gavin Aung Than:** Yeah, so my dad – I think I must get his sense of independence – he opened up his own print shop in our house actually. We had the print shop. He had a little room extension on the house. So, I would help him, even though I hated it. I would, reluctantly. I would help with the typesetting. What would we use back then? QuarkXPress. God, I hate QuarkXPress. I get nightmares thinking about it.

**Gabe:** Occasionally a cheesecake recipe comes up and it asks for quark cheese, and all I can think of is desktop publishing software.

**Gavin:** So, I would help my dad in his business, and I was there when he was printing the pages. This comic [‘Devil Hands’] means a lot to me. 

**Gabe:** So, it was a family business running from the back of the house?

**Gavin:** Yeah. My mum helped with the bookkeeping and stuff.

**Gabriel:** So, would it have been offset printing? 

**Gavin:** Yeah, he had a two-colour machine. If you had to print four colours, you have to run it through the press twice. He started off with a one-colour machine that was in my bedroom, which was illegal. He kicked me out of my bedroom! I had to change bedrooms. And then he eventually built an extension to the house and he bought a two-colour machine and he had a pretty successful little business that he ran for about 20 years. 

**Gabe:** So, your family, they migrated here, did you say? 

**Gavin:** Yeah, they migrated from Burma – Myanmar now – in the seventies before I was born. So, I'm very thankful that I got to grow up as an Australian and not have to grow up there. I have visited there once. I actually had a Zen Pencils meetup there, which is one of my best experiences that I've had. 

**Gabe:** So, when you went back to Burma with Zen Pencils, have you got family still there?

**Gavin:** No. So my parents went back on a holiday. And I went back for a holiday, but, for tax purposes, I had a little Zen Pencils meetup there. I thought, no one's gonna come, no one in Burma is reading Zen Pencils webcomics. There wasn't a huge crowd there, but it was about 20 people that came and it was really awesome.

Just to go back to the motherland with my parents, and they showed me around where they grew up and stuff like that. It was a good experience. 

**Gabe:** Have you managed to publish any Zen Pencils over there? 

**Gavin:** Not Burma, no. There's been a Vietnamese edition, and there's been a Korean edition, a French edition and that's it. 

**Gabe:** You talked about [the quotes in Zen Pencils] mainly being white dudes. Did that shift also how you choose to _draw_ anything, as far as representation of the people telling the story?

**Gavin:** Yeah, it made me broaden my scope. So, I was doing a lot more quotes from females. And I was drawing more diverse characters. Growing up in a Western country, that's how you're brought up. All my characters were white, all the people I was quoting were white. And you just step back and you look at it and go, ‘Yeah, that's totally right. Why am I doing that?’ 

**Gabe:** It’s amazing to hear about your home printing. 

**Gavin:** Yeah. He worked with a finishing company who binded it and stapled it and guillotined it. They helped with some of my projects around uni.
fields.pullQuote: Yeah, he had a two-colour machine. If you had to print four colours, you have to run it through the press twice. He started off with a one-colour machine that was in my bedroom, which was illegal. He kicked me out of my bedroom! I had to change bedrooms. And then he eventually built an extension to the house and he bought a two-colour machine and he had a pretty successful little business that he ran for about 20 years.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Dad's Print Shop

fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** So, did you actually interact with any Australian comics at that time?

**Gavin Aung Than:** Yeah, I joined the Australian Cartoonists Association around that time. I was going to a few meetings. But, they were older. And they were more interested in old comic strips and political cartoons, stuff like that, which I was not interested in. I mean I went to meetings in Melbourne quite a bit. Trying to be part of a community, but again, I was not the most social person and they're not my age at all. So that didn't work out. I did meet Jason Chatfield there, which I'll talk about later. So that was the main organization I thought would be my tribe, but that didn't really eventuate. 

**Gabe:** There's something I've seen reflected around newspaper comics and political cartooning around, I guess, context or history and the silo of those sorts of communities. Is that what you found when you were doing your newspaper strip? How did you interact with the newspaper comics people or cartoonists when you were doing the actual published strips? Did they give you feedback or positive inclusion?

**Gavin:** Yeah, they were nice about it. That's when I was doing ‘Dan and Pete’. And I joined the ACA in Melbourne. There were a few guys who were very nice and supportive. Some of them were doing their own little strips or webcomics and stuff like that. Jason was the most supportive, cause we're a similar age, and he's deep into that world of newspaper strips. 

**Gabe:** There’s black-and-white traditional political cartooning, and then you look at other things which aren't one-panel political comics, and there's this cognitive dissonance that occurs.

**Gavin:** Yeah. They're part of the same thing, but _not,_ at the same time.

**Meg O’Shea:** They're cousins who don't like each other.

You said you were hoping that the ACA would be a tribe, so was finding community something you felt like you needed at some point? 

**Gabe:** It's a good question. I've thought about it a lot since I've seen what you're gonna be asking me about. Thankfully, through Zen Pencils, I found people, but they were not Australian. They were other artists from around the world. A lot in America. I built up connections through Twitter, which is the beauty of social media.

When I was in Melbourne, I was just fully in Zen Pencils. That was everything. It took up my whole life basically. And then I moved to Perth. There's a really good community here, but I haven't really had much to do with it, which is my own fault. Plus, when I moved back there was a pandemic and then we had our second kid, we had a second daughter. There's not really much time to do professional networking and stuff like that. 

**Meg: **Was there something about being in Melbourne, away from your hometown, that made you feel like you needed to establish connection?

**Gavin:** Yeah, that's a good question. Thankfully I made a good group of friends through my work. So, I worked in newspapers in Melbourne for four to five years. And I was doing ACA meetings, they became acquaintances. I went to a few of their conferences. I just felt, ‘I'm sure there are other cartoonists around, maybe we should hang out or something.’ I made some weak attempts at trying to make friends, but I'm not the greatest at that.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Networking With Other Newspaper cartoonists

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: An image from Gaving's Zen Pencils Webcomic (mohammad Ali, bruce Lee)
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** In the comics you were doing in the newspaper strips, and then also Zen Pencils, what are the themes that you're exploring? What are the sort of themes that you return to or you come back to when you're making these stories?

**Gavin Aung Than:** The newspaper strips were just fun, superhero escapism stuff, more aimed at kids. But Zen Pencils was all about self-motivation and inspiration and building in my own knowledge of science and history, and just combining everything I loved, basically.

Zen Pencils is all about positivity. And joy, I guess. It's really helped a lot of people around the world. It's just basically inspirational quotes, but done in comics. 

**Gabe:** Do you use inspirational quotes in your own life?

**Gavin:** Yeah, the origin of it was all kind of wrapped up in my own life, where I was questioning what I was doing. I just kept doing these two little strips in newspapers, which no one was really reading. And my newspaper job was not fulfilling at all.

I had a few of my own quotes, and I was reading a lot of biographies and stuff like that, to motivate myself. So, my main kind of heroes that I used on the site: Bruce Lee was one of them. So, he's a classic hero for young Asian men around the world. He's got some quotes. Muhammad Ali's another one. His biography is really good. George Carlin, the comedian, I was really into his work around that time, so I did some of his quotes.
 
I did stuff that I loved. They were helping me to actually just do it: do what I wanted to do, which is comics. They formed the basis of the first few Zen Pencils, and then people started sending me their favourite quotes. 

I was reading more history, biographies and scientists’ biographies. And it all coalesced into Zen Pencils, and it helped me personally. It helped me get over the hump of doing comics as a job. And it helped a lot of people.

**Gabe:** It must feel remarkable to have someone communicate the impact of your work in a positive way like that.

**Gavin:** Yeah, it's really been humbling and very nice. 

**Gabe:** Are there any stories around the messages you've received from readers?

**Gavin:** Yeah, there's been heaps.

I did a strip about domestic violence, and a few domestic violence survivors said that it really helped them. I've done one about a closeted gay man comes out and I got a few messages from gay people saying that it really hit home.
fields.bigText: Making a Webcomic Around Inspirational Quotes
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Making a Webcomic Around Inspirational Quotes

fields.image_alt: An Image of an ipad with the Bill Watterson comic comic on display.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gavin Aung Than:** So _the_ most popular Zen Pencils comic is this, the quote I use from Bill Watterson, who's creator of _Calvin & Hobbes,_ which is probably my favourite newspaper strip. So, I took a quote from a speech he made. I took those words and I turned into a strip, and I aped his style as well, the way he laid out panels and stuff like that.  The story was semi-autobiographical. This guy working a corporate design job, he leaves. He leaves his design job to do his own thing at home. He becomes a stay-at-home dad, working from home. Just very obviously influenced by Bill Watterson. This comic blew up. It went viral and it got shared many, many times around the world. It was the culmination of Zen Pencils where it's my own story, my favourite artist. It's the most popular comic. People could see that it meant a lot to me. And then a lot of people said it meant a lot to them. Some people said it inspired them to leave their own job and do what they wanted to do. 
**Gabriel Clark:** Your ability to mimic the style like that, how easy is that? Like how do you go about doing something like that? **Gavin:** Firstly, let me say I came nowhere close to, [Watterson’s] craftsmanship. I had all his strips laid out in front of me and as I was making the comic and. It was just a fun challenge to draw like Bill Watterson. I obviously have some of his influence in my natural style. But to go into full Bill Watterson mode, it was just fun. A fun little project.  It actually showed up on Reddit just last week again, and a lot of people found it for the first time. I got an email from someone saying they just saw it and they fell in love with Zen Pencils, and now they're going through the Zen Pencils archives, for the first time. So, it's great that it's there online for anyone to find.  **Meg O’Shea: **How many years into doing Zen Pencils full time did you make this one?  **Gavin:** It's got the little year at the bottom. So, just over a year, 2013. This was the second year where the website was really blowing up. It was getting a lot of hits and stuff like that. **Meg: **Is this a way to document or reflect on what had happened? **Gavin:** Yeah, so I knew I wanted to do a Bill Watterson quote, cause he's one of my personal heroes. And I guess the story just came from my own life. I wrote this essay about Bill Watterson as well, underneath the comic as a blog post. His own story is really inspiring as well.  **Gabe:** I always think of the comparisons of Bill Watterson and Jim Davis.  **Gavin:** One’s really, really, really rich. And one's just really rich.  **Meg:** Only one had a failed theme park ride. **Gabe:** Watterson famously banned any merchandise didn't he?  **Gavin:** So, Bill Watterson, just think of it, he did that strip for 10 years. Age 28 to 38. Retired. Never heard from again. He came out from the woodwork a few years ago to do a few guest comics, but yeah, very reclusive. Doesn't need any attention. And yeah, famously did not merchandise, ever. Just imagine how many like Hobbes soft toys would've sold around the world. Just imagine that. Yeah, that's a pretty principled, man. I don't know if I would've said ‘No’ to that. **Gabe:** So that blew up in 2013.  **Gavin:** Yeah. So, for me, that artefact represents the whole Zen Pencils period of my career.  So, the way that I got the book deal was actually a pretty good story as well. I did a quote from Roger Ebert, the film critic, when he died. I did a quote from him which is one of my favourite Zen Pencils that I've done. And I got this email saying, ‘Oh, I saw the Roger Ebert comic. I'm actually his editor, for his books.’ I was like, ‘Okay.’ That's all, it stopped there. And then I noticed his publisher is Andrews McMeel, and I was like, ‘ding ding ding’. And I knew they had published The Oatmeal books, which were really successful. And obviously they published Calvin and Hobbes, and they publish all the big comic strip anthologies. And so, I just emailed back saying, ‘Oh, thank you, blah blah, blah would you be interested in it a Zen Pencils book?’ And then she said, ‘Oh, I'll get back to you on that.’ And that's how the book deal came about. **Gabe:** That's great. **Gavin:** That sounds very lucky and all. And it is. But it's by putting your work out there, it’s built up an audience.
fields.bigText: The Bill Watterson Comic that Went Viral
fields.pullQuote: It was the culmination of Zen Pencils where it's my own story, my favourite artist. It's the most popular comic. People could see that it meant a lot to me. And then a lot of people said it meant a lot to them. Some people said it inspired them to leave their own job and do what they wanted to do.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on The Bill Watterson Comic that Went Viral

fields.image_alt: A CAROUSEL of pages from Gavin's Comic based on a Bill Watterson quote.
fields.Copy_rt: placeholder text
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Placeholder copy

fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** Being entrepreneurial, do you think that's a key skill that you need in Australian comics?

**Gavin Aung Than:** Yes. Yes. Zen Pencils was all-consuming. It was not just me making comics, it was me doing the social media, doing the emails, doing the website hosting, doing the website design, doing the posters. I would redesign the comics as posters. That took a lot of work. I had to set up the eCommerce store, online store, and the drop shipping. You have to have that business side of you.

**Gabe: **Where did that come from? Knowing how to run a business?

**Gavin:** I still don’t know how to run a business! Constant failure I guess.

**Gabe: **Was it also your family upbringing? 

**Gavin:**  It must have been. Some of that must have seeped in through me my dad. Cause he was working in a regular print factory, and he eventually said, ‘Screw this, I don't want to work for a boss anymore.’ So, he eventually did his own thing and that's what I did as well. Just learning by figuring it out as you go.

**Gabe:** How’s your family now, about your career? 

**Gavin:** Yeah, they're good now. They just worry about, ‘Is he making enough money? How is he gonna pay his bills?’ And that's all they care about. But they're proud of me now. They've come to a few book signings and stuff like that, and they pose with me. The readers talk to them and they're like, ‘Oh yeah, he gets his artistic side from me,’ and stuff like that. It's all good now.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on The Business of Full-time Comics

fields.image_alt: A Photograph of Gavin's Graphic novel 'Super Sidekicks'
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** So what other artefacts are there? Let’s show some stuff.

**Gavin Aung Than:** So, the third artefact is one of my books. This represents my period that I'm doing now. This is a _Super Sidekicks _book. This is a series I've been working on the last few years. There are three books. 

After Zen Pencils, I wanted to write my own stories. With Zen Pencils, there were some issues with the quotes. Sometimes I couldn't print them as posters because they were copyrighted passages. In the book collections, a lot of the advance I got was spent on getting licenses to use the quotes to put in the book, which is not very good business. Say you get a $10,000 advance, which sounds great, but maybe $8,000 is spent on the licenses. 

So there were a few factors in why I wanted to stop Zen Pencils. One was I felt I'd done everything I could with it. I was getting a bit bored doing the inspirational quote thing. One was financial reasons. And one was I saw graphic novels were massive, were blowing up. Kids’ graphic novels in particular with Raina Telgemeier, and _Bad Guys_ and _Dog Man_ and stuff like that. I knew the _Bad Guys_ was an Australian creation. And I wanted to do that. _Super Sidekicks _was my attempt at that. I loved superheroes growing up. I wanted to make a superhero story for kids that I would've loved as a kid.

I've created this Australian superhero team called the Super Sidekicks. There are three books that came out in Australia, and it got picked up by an American publisher. This is one of the American hardback editions, which kind of represents my dream basically, which is my work in beautiful hardcover in full colour.

The Australian books were black-and-white. The American one is in colour. It’s set in Australia. They have their headquarters in Sydney Harbour. I thought, why not have an Australian superhero team? 

**Gabe:** How did that go with the American publisher?

**Gavin: **Yeah, so that's a good question. I wanted to do JJ as a brown skinned hero as I have brown skin. So, he looks a bit like me. When it was bought by an American publisher they were happy leaving it set in Australia. But this character here, Fly Girl, she speaks with a heavy Australian accent and they were like, ‘Maybe you could turn down the number of “mates” that she could say.’ And I was like, ‘No, actually I like it that she's an Australian.’ She's a very dinky-di Aussie type of character. And so I fought for her to keep her Australian-ness. I'm glad that I did that. 
This represents what I'm working on now. There are three books. I'm not sure if there's gonna be any more. I don't think there is. This is book number two. This is probably my favourite one. It won the Australian Environment Award for children's literature a couple of years ago. 

**Gabe:** What's that award for?

**Gavin: **Just children's literature which has a positive environmental message, which this book does. So, I'm proud of that, so that's why I brought this one in.
fields.pullQuote: This is one of the American hardback editions, which kind of represents my dream basically, which is my work in beautiful hardcover in full colour.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on The "Super Sidekicks" Series

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: A photograph of an appropriate page of 'Super Sidekicks'
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** What are the kind of visual kind of tricks you used, tools you used to show Australia versus say a kung-fu comic or say a Bill Watterson water thing? How do you make it feel visually Australian?

**Gavin Aung Than:** Like I said the headquarters is in Sydney Harbour, so I drew the Harbour Bridge and Opera House. And Bondi Beach is a setting. It's not really looking like Bondi, it's just a beach. 

**Meg O’Shea: **Is there any particular reason why you chose to have them headquartered in Sydney? 

**Gavin:** Just the iconic landmarks, which is more recognizable. You can see Sydney in the background there. 

**Gabe:** Is that about ease of communication so that people just get it?

**Gavin:** Yeah, just visually symbolic. Sydney is a bit more iconic than Perth. 

So, this story has a giant monster made out of plastic in the oceans, that comes out, comes alive and destroys Sydney.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Australian Worldbuilding

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: a process document such as a sketch or a page of original art.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** And what was the impetus for the plot of the Super Sidekicks? 

**Gavin Aung Than:** So I had just read an article about the Pacific garbage patch. And I thought, what if all that plastic became sentient and formed a creature and took revenge on humans. And that became the plot. The ocean wants revenge on humanity for what we've done. 

**Meg O’Shea: **What's your process for this? Do you script everything first?

**Gavin:** Yeah, so I script and thumbnail at the same time.

**Gabe:** Do you do that digitally? 

**Gavin:** No, it's all just done in a notebook. I obviously write the script out on a computer, but yeah, the thumbnails are done just in a legal pad. And then I pencil and do the lettering. I still use InDesign from my graphic design days. I love InDesign. I use InDesign a lot and Photoshop a lot. So that's why I don't say my graphic design years were wasted because those were very valuable tools that I now use pretty much every day in my comic making.

**Gabe:** So do you do your colouring digitally, and you inking and drawing?

**Gavin:** The inking is done traditionally. Colouring is done digitally. But someone else coloured this thankfully. 

**Gabe:** And when it was black-and-white [in the Australian edition], were you using more halftones or shading?

**Gavin:** Yeah, I did grey, just grey colour in Photoshop.

**Meg:** So you're not a fan of colouring? 

**Gavin:** I can live without it. I can do it. But I would rather be making more comics, and hiring a colourist. Not to sound arrogant or anything like that, I could colour, but I just feel like if someone else is willing to colour it, then I can make other stories.
 
**Meg:** Are you using a brush?

**Gavin:** I use mainly pens and brush pens. 

**Gabriel:** On Bristol board, that whole setup?

**Gavin:** My dad being a printer, I just used a stock that I found a lot cheaper than Bristol board.

You’d always read those comic interviews: ‘You have to use 11 by 17 Bristol board, and you have to use a quill pen and a Winsor & Newton brush.’ I tried all that. It's too expensive. I just use a print stock that I found is quite good, that I like, and I use Micron pens mainly.
fields.pullQuote: I use InDesign a lot and Photoshop a lot. So that's why I don't say my graphic design years were wasted because those were very valuable tools that I now use pretty much every day in my comic making.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on The Process for 'Super Sidekicks'

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: The Image of Jason and Gavin.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark: **What other artefacts have we got?

**Gavin Aung Than:** So, I brought a couple of photos.

I mentioned Jason Chatfield. Jason, he's another Perth boy. This photo was of me and him at New York Comic Con. 

**Gabe: **Oh, what was that like? 

**Gavin:** So like I said, in 2015 I was lucky that my publisher sent me to America and I got to do a book tour for my second Zen Pencils book.

Jason and I had met 10 years earlier in Perth. I remember my first ACA meeting and he was a shy kid, and I was a shy kid, and we didn't really talk, but I knew Jason. I followed his work and then he got the big gig of being the next Ginger Meggs cartoonist. He's currently still doing that.

He moved to Melbourne as well. I moved to Melbourne as well. He lived there. So, we met a few times there in Melbourne. And eventually he moved to New York. He's also a comedian, so he's working as a comedian. He's the hardest working guy I know. 

He is a comedian, full-time comic strip artist, and he's also the president of the NCS which is the National Cartoonist Society in America. It’s the equivalent of the ACA in America, but it's massive. This Perth boy is the president of the whole thing. I just thought the photo was cool, like where we had come from and where we were at that time, where we were both living our dreams working on comics.

I was at New York, got to go to Comic-Con. So yeah, that's why I thought the photo's pretty cool. We still keep in touch and he's been a very big supporter of my work.
fields.bigText: His Friendship with The Australian Cartoonist Jason Chatfield
fields.pullQuote: I just thought the photo was cool, like where we had come from and where we were at that time, where we were both living our dreams working on comics.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on His Friendship with The Australian Cartoonist Jason Chatfield

fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** What was being on the hustle of New York Comic-Con like? 

**Gavin Aung Than:** I was lucky enough the year before, 2014, I went to San Diego Comic-Con. That was a dream come true to go to Comic-Con. Then New York Comic-Con was a similar type of thing. It was just crazy. Just, hordes of people, hordes of geeks who all love the same thing you do. It's a bit overwhelming but it was a lot of fun. 

**Gabe:** I guess the hustle of being in that sort of space versus the sort of the hustle here, you could work more in isolation here. Do you perceive that as a barrier here for comics?

**Gavin:** It was a barrier for me, when I was starting out being in Perth. Australia's comic industry wasn't, was nil around then. It was more like political comics, newspaper comics and stuff like that. So I thought it was a barrier, but today I don't think it's really a barrier cause of the internet, of social media. You interviewed Sarah [Winifred Searle], she's got a US book deal. Campbell [Whyte]'s obviously working with US publishers. I'm working with US publishers. There's no barriers I guess, cause we're examples that there isn't.

**Gabe:** If you were to try and set up Zen comics now, given the way image sharing works and stuff like that, do you think it'd be a different experience? Harder, easier?

**Gavin:** I think it would be harder now. It'd probably be easier to find an audience. Instagram has made a lot of people become big with comics, have a big audience. But monetizing that is another question. That's another challenge. The age of the blog site is dead. No one has blogs anymore. People don't really visit websites anymore. They all get their content through social media, through Instagram, Facebook. They always click through that. Back when I first had my Facebook page, there was no boosting of posts and stuff like that. Now if you wanna reach your full audience, you have to pay, you have to boost it. Same with Instagram. So it is hard. It's easy to find an audience, hard to turn that into a living.

**Gabe:** Are you noticing that that's having impacts on your current practice?

**Gavin:** That's another reason I moved away from the webcomic world because you are basically controlled by the social media company now. Say if I've got a hundred thousand followers and I want to promote a new book, maybe like 2000 of those followers will actually see it organically. And you have to pay for it to reach your entire audience. 

**Gabe:** Entrepreneurial mindset coming in again.

**Gavin:** So that's why I'm trying to work more with traditional publishing.
fields.bigText: The Hustle Then and the Hustle Now
fields.pullQuote: It's easy to find an Audience and hard to turn that into a living.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on The Hustle Then and the Hustle Now

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: An image from Home Time
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** Oh, you've got another thing over there, is that Campbell's book?

**Gavin Aung Than:** Yeah, I was asked to bring in a comic by an Australian that I really like, so I brought Campbell's _Home Time_. 

Again, another Perth cartoonist. I think I moved back to Perth four years ago, and I think this came out maybe three years ago. I got my hands on it and I was just blown away by Campbell's work. I really love it. And the fact that he set it in Perth. I've always been embarrassed that I'm from Perth, but he's embraced it and he's set his comic in Perth. I was just really impressed by his story, his craft, the amount of work and dedication that he put into it. I'm glad he's getting recognized for it. 

**Gabe:** Is there any particular page or panel?

**Gavin:** I just love all the different styles. There's just so much. The pixel art! 

**Gabe:** I don't know Perth, so which bits is it?

**Gavin:** When they go to the fish and chip shop, that's something I did, just getting a bag of chips.

**Gabe:** And are they particular locations that you know?

**Gavin:** There's a vibe. Like a bit of a Perth vibe to it. And I could just tell that he used Perth as an inspiration. He says a WA in some of the work. I just really think it's great work.

**Gabe:** I think that process of using a location to inform story is really interesting.

**Gavin:** That's something I'm not great at. 

**Gabe:** Is that something you're planning? 

**Gavin:** Yeah. The graphic novel I'm working on now, the setting plays a large role in it.

I'm having trouble building the world. Doing the world building. I'm not good at that. It's a fantasy world building. I've never been good at world building. I've always liked just throwing the characters in I wish someone else would draw the other stuff!

**Gabe:** Do you use references and stuff for characters?

**Gavin:** Not really. I just do a lot of character design and stuff like that, but I do need a lot of reference for the setting.

**Gabe:** Yeah. Other people have spoken about the way they use references to inform their stuff. So there'll be 3D models or they'll build sculptures.  Do you have processes like that?

**Gavin:** I've used some models. Some of the Zen Pencils stuff, for the backgrounds. Mainly for mechanical stuff. I'm not good at drawing cars and planes and stuff like that.
fields.pullQuote: I've always been embarrassed that I'm from Perth, but he's embraced it and he's set his comic in Perth.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Campbell Whyte and 'Home Time'

fields.image_alt: SUGEGSTED: An image from the new project.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Meg O’Shea:** Is there any particular theme you're diving into with the new series?

**Gavin Aung Than: **The new series is for kids again. It's a fantastical story. It's set in a hospital for mythical creatures. So it's all about the staff that works there. They deal with all the various injuries mythical creatures have. It's a bit light-hearted. It's fun. 

There's a couple of themes that have emerged. I guess one is prejudice, dealing with your parents' prejudices and being informed by it, and then forming your own opinion once you come across the actual, person or race that they're prejudiced against. That's come out, which has been nice.

====== CHECK =======
And the main conflict is between the mother and daughter, which reflects my own history, with my mother. Don't tell her that. That’s based around my own relationship with my mother. 
====== CHECK =======

**Gabe:** That sounds like a book I wanna read.

**Meg: **When you're writing stuff for kids, are you approaching the content in terms of, ‘I wish I'd known this when I was a kid,’ that kind of thing. 

**Gavin: **No. It's more just writing stories for my daughters, basically. I've got two daughters, that's why the protagonist is a girl. I just make it for them. Hopefully they'll read it when they're a little bit older. 

**Gabriel:** Do you see there's a need for stories for young girls?

**Gavin:** It’s definitely become more diverse and there's more female-led stories the last few years, which has been great. No, I don't really feel there's an extra need for it, but it obviously doesn't hurt to have more.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on His Forthcoming Kids Series

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: An old comic that Reflect
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabe:** With the development of your style and your visual voice, are there any influences that you can think of there? 

**Gavin:** Yeah, so there’s Bill Watterson, one of the main ones. I always mention Jack Kirby cause there's no superhero comics without Jack Kirby. 

**Gabe:** Would his work be influencing your visual style?

**Gavin:** No, mainly just energy basically. Just not to have boring characters standing still. Always have movement, energy, big action. That really helped with the superhero series I did. 

Chuck Jones is another big influence. Looney Tunes was a big influence growing up. Chuck Jones was my favourite Looney Tunes director. His humour, his facial expressions. Angular kind of cartooniness. 

I've done a Zen Pencils comic about a quote from Chuck Jones too.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Developing His Art Style

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: A scan of the panel made by Bruce Mutard.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gavin Aung Than:** I brought in a panel from Bruce Mutard’s _The Sacrifice_ graphic novel. 

I think it came out like around 2009, 2010. I was working in the newspaper in Melbourne at that time. They had this cool agreement where the book reviewer would get sent books every week, mountains of books. He obviously couldn't review them all. So anyone could take a book as long as they would review it. I saw _The Sacrifice_ was there one day and I was like, ‘Oh, what's this? A comic. I love comics.’ And so I took it and I was like, ‘Wow, it’s an Australian artist.’

I was just blown away by Bruce's work and his draftsmanship and the level of work. This is just one example of one panel in like maybe thousands of panels, hundreds of panels that he did for that book. Just all that work into one panel, the composition, the amount of detail, the framing.

It just really impressed me. The fact that it was an Aussie cartoonist was really cool. Bruce, if you're listening, I think I did review the book if you remember a review in MX Newspaper many years ago. That was me.

 Bruce's work really keeps you honest.

**Gabriel Clark:** When you say it keeps you honest, what do you mean by that?

**Gavin:** Basically, don't be complacent and always try to improve your own work because the fact that an artist would put this amount of work into just one panel is inspiring. To keep pushing your own work. Cause I could probably never do that. And I probably wouldn't. Why the hell would I do that? And then the fact that he would. It's inspiring. 

**Meg O’Shea: **Inspirational, not necessarily aspirational.

**Gabriel:** Just wondering about this scene in context. The thing I recall about 'The Sacrifice' is that _every_ panel feels this detailed, every panel has this level of depth, but the simplicity in the communication seems really clear about what narrative elements are happening in each frame.

**Gavin:** Yeah. Just the amount of thought that's gone into it. You don't just start drawing on a board. The amount of thought that goes into that layout.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Bruce Mutard's 'The Sacrifice'
Gavin Aung Than on

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: an example of Gavin's typography process. Hand lettering examples? Photo of his lettering?
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** When you're laying out your action scene, say _Sidekicks_, you're thinking in broad strokes in your thumbnails, you're planning out those action points in that Jack Kirby-inspired way? 

**Gavin Aung Than:** Basically you just want it to be clear, and not boring. 

**Gabek:** One thing I noticed with your uni project zine is that already your type was clear and legible, compared to my experience teaching university students.

**Gavin:** Typography is a whole discipline. Comics encompasses all of that stuff.

**Gabriel:** Are you frustrated with the need for to be across 15 disciplines in your art form? 

**Gavin:** With comics, you are director and you're a typographer, you're a character designer, you're a production designer. You're doing all these different things. You love it or you just do something else. 

Typography is a sticking point for me. When I pick up a comic and the typography is not good, I turn my nose up.

**Gabe:** Do you use fonts or do you do hand lettering?

**Gavin:** I used to do hand lettering, but now it's all done in InDesign. 

**Gabe:** Is the font made from your own handwriting?

**Gavin:** Yeah, so the one I'm doing now for my graphic novel is based on my own handwriting. 

**Meg O’Shea:** Is that something you did for yourself or is it more cause your work's probably going to be translated? 

**Gavin:** I guess I've always wanted my own font, which is cool to have. Those comic strips I would do the hand lettering and it was always a pain in the butt to do the hand lettering. So, I thought wouldn't it be easier just to have it as a font.

One of the things I've noticed for the kids’ graphic novels is they're using upper-lower case font, which is not traditional. With comics, it's always traditionally been uppercase. The font that I'm using based on my own is an upper-lower case. I think cause it's aimed at kids. Kids read upper-lowercase easier. I think that's why it's used a bit more these days where it was probably the hardcore traditionalists would be like, ‘No, it's gotta be uppercase’. You gotta design it for your audience. 

**Gabe:** When you're thinking about your audience for your books, how much of that is you intuitively going ‘I’m designing for my audience,’ and how much is that the editor going, ‘Your audience is _x_. It hit this mark.’

**Gavin:** It's a bit of both. But yeah, I chose to use the upper-lowercase font, that was my decision. I've noticed my daughter reads upper-lowercase better than uppercase. She's still young. She's only six. You do have to keep your audience in mind, otherwise you're just being stubborn.
fields.bigText: Layout, Typography and Lettering for Kid's Comics
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Layout, Typography and Lettering for Kid's Comics

fields.image_alt: SUGGESTED: An Image of the characters from the "Sidekicks" series.
fields.Copy_rt:
**Gabriel Clark:** You were talking about having Australia in _Sidekicks_, but are there other editorial impacts due to publishing stuff for kids?

**Gavin Aung Than:** My Australian publisher was a lot more easy-going, laid-back. But when I went to America there were a lot more little things that they changed.

So one of the adult superhero characters I changed to have more of a Latin character. They want to include more diversity. And they're much more cautious about offending people in America. I find they're very picky about, ‘You can't say this, you can't say that. It might offend these people. It might offend those people.’

**Gab:** Does that mean they had someone who would go through and say, ‘You gotta think this through,’? 

**Gavin:** I think they do. Some of the big houses have sensitivity readers or sensitivity people that do go over all that stuff. I think it's great. Obviously we want more diverse characters and stuff.

**Gabe:** It's a hundred percent important. It is an interesting process when you think about the inherited biases we have. 

**Meg: **It's also interesting that diversity wasn't an issue for Australian publishers. Letting it go ahead. 

**Gabe:** Do you think that your experience being the children of immigrants in Australia gives you a little more sort of intuitive expertise in that sort of space?

**Gavin:** Not so much expertise, but just a bit more awareness. That's why I made the main character look like me. Cause when I was growing up, all my superhero leaders were white. A kid these days wants to see themselves represented more.  

**Gabe:** I think you're right. It's vital. 

Well, Gavin, you've survived the interrogation. [laughs] Thanks for taking the time to do this interview with us.
fields.name: Gavin Aung Than on Diversity and Representation
